The epigenetic reader SntB was identified as an important transcriptional regulator of 25 growth, development, and secondary metabolite synthesis in Aspergillus flavus. 26 However, the underlying molecular mechanism is still unclear. In this study, sntB gene 27 deletion (ΔsntB), complementary (Com-sntB), and HA tag fused to snt2 (snt2-HA) 28 strains were constructed by using the homologous recombination method, respectively. 29 Our results revealed that deletion of sntB inhibited the processes of mycelia growth, 30 conidial production, sclerotia formation, aflatoxin synthesis, and ability to colonize 31 host compared to wild type (WT), and the defective phenotype of knockout strain 32 ΔsntB can be restored by its complementary strain Com-sntB. Chromatin 33 immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) of sntB-HA and WT and RNA 34 sequencing (RNA-seq) of ΔsntB and WT strains revealed that SntB played key roles 35 in oxidative stress response of A. flavus. The function of catC (encode a catalase) 36 gene was further analyzed based on the integration results of ChIP-seq and RNA-seq. 37 In ∆sntB strain, the relative expression level of catC was significantly higher than in 38 WT strain, while a secretory lipase encoding gene (G4B84_008359) was 39 down-regulated. Under the stress of oxidant menadione sodium bisulfite (MSB), the 40 deletion of sntB obvious down-regulated the expression level of catC. After deletion 41 of catC gene, the mycelia growth, conidial production, and sclerotia formation were 42 inhibited, while aflatoxin synthesis was increased compared to the WT strain. Results 43 also showed that the inhibition rate of MSB to ΔcatC strain was significantly lower 44 than that of WT group and AFB1 yield of the ΔcatC strain was significantly decreased 45
than that of WT strain under the stress of MSB. Our study revealed the potential 46 machinery that SntB regulated fungal morphogenesis, mycotoxin anabolism, and 47 fungal virulence through the axle of from SntB to fungal virulence and mycotoxin 48 bio-synthesis, i.e. H3K36me3 modification-SntB-Peroxisomes-Lipid 49 hydrolysis-fungal virulence and mycotoxin bio-synthesis. The results of the study 50 shad light into the SntB mediated epigenetic regulation pathway of fungal mycotoxin 51 anabolism and virulence, which provided potential strategy for control the 52 contamination of A. flavus and its aflatoxins. 53

1. Introduction 59 Aspergillus flavus is one of the common asexual species, a saprophytic fungus and the 60 second largest pathogenic fungus after Aspergillus fumigatus, widely distributed in 61
soil, air, water, plants, and agricultural products in nature [1] . Aflatoxins produced by A. 62 flavus has strong toxicity, and is extremely harmful to human society. Animal and 63 human health can be negatively affected by aflatoxins, which are carcinogenic, 64
teratogenic, and mutagenic [2] . Among aflatoxins, AFB1 is the most frequently 65 occurring and the most toxic and carcinogenic, which is converted to AFB1-8 and 66 9-epoxide in the liver and formed adducts with the guanine base of DNA and thus 67
results in acute and chronic diseases in both human and household animals [3] . 68 According to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 25% of 69
the food crops in the world are contaminated with aflatoxins [4] , which are often 70
detected in grains, nuts, and spices [5, 6] . It is urgent to control the contamination of A. 71 flavus and its main mycotoxin, AFB1. 72 In recent decades, the biosynthetic pathway of aflatoxins was investigated in detail 73
benefit from the sequence of A. flavus genome [7] . This pathway consists of a complex 74
set of enzymatic reactions [8-11] . In general, these enzymes are encoded by clusters of 75
genes, which are regulated by cluster-specific genes: aflR and aflS [12, 13] . The initial 76 stage of aflatoxins biosynthesis is catalyzed by polyketide synthase (PKSA) to form 77
the polyketone backbone [14] . Aflatoxins synthesis also regulated by environmental 78 stimuli including pH, light, nutrient sources, and oxidative stress response, which may 79
result in the modulation of the expression of genes involved in toxin production [15-17] . 80
Besides the biosynthetic pathway and its internal gene regulation, protein 81 post-translational modifications (PTMs), an important mean of epigenetics, represent 82 an important role in the regulation of aflatoxins synthesis, including 83
2-hydroxyisobutyrylation, succinylation, acetylation, and methylation [18-24] , in which 84 Snt2 (also called sntB, an epigenetic reader) is deeply involved. Despite 85 advancements in the field, our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of 86 aflatoxin production in A. flavus is still fragmentary. 87 The epigenetic reader encoded by sntB in A. nidulans was identified as a 88 transcriptional regulator of the sterigmatocystin biosynthetic gene cluster and 89
deletion of sntB gene in A. flavus results in loss of aflatoxin production [25] , increasing 90 global levels of H3K9K14 acetylation and impairing several developmental processes 91 [20] . The homolog gene in yeast, SNT2 coordinates the transcriptional response to 92
hydrogen peroxide stress [26, 27] . In Penicillium expansum, SntB regulated the 93
development, patulin and citrinin production, and virulence on apples [28] . In A. 94 nidulans, SntB combined with a H3K4 histone demethylase KdmB, a cohesin 95 acetyltransferase (EcoA), and a histone deacetylase (RpdA) to form a chromatin 96 binding complex and bound to regulatory genes and coordinated fungal development 97
with mycotoxin synthesis [29] . sntB also regulated the virulence in Fusarium 98
oxysporum, and respiration in F. oxysporum and Neurospora crassa [30, 31] . 99
However, the specific regulatory mechanism of sntB in A. flavus remains unclear. In 100 this study, we identified the regulatory network of sntB by Chromatin 101
immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) and RNA sequencing (RNA-seq), which 102 shed light on its impact on fungal biology. 103 Experimental Procedures 104 A. flavus strains, media, and culture conditions 105 A. flavus Δku70 ΔpyrG was used as a host strain for genetic manipulations. All strains 106 used in this study are listed in the Table 1. potato dextrose agar (PDA, 39 g/L, BD, 107 Difco, Franklin, NJ, USA), complete medium (CM, 6 g/L tryptone, 6 g/L yeast extract, 108 10 g/L glucose), and potato dextrose (PDB, 24 g/L, BD, Difco, Franklin, NJ, USA) 109 were used for mycelial growth and sporulation determination, sclerotia production, 110 and mycotoxin production analysis, respectively. All experiments were technically 111 repeated three times and biologically repeated three times. 112

The difference was considered to be statistically significant when 186 P<0.05. 187 Results 188 The phenotype of SntB in A. flavus 189 The role of SntB in A. flavus has been previously characterized by analyzing both 190
ΔsntB and overexpression sntB genetic mutants [20] . To further investigate the intrinsic 191 mechanism of this regulator on the development and aflatoxin biosynthesis in A. 192 flavus, the sntB deletion strain (∆sntB) and the complementary strain (Com-sntB) 193 were constructed by the method of homologous recombination and verified by 194 diagnostic PCR and southern blotting (Figure S1). The expression levels of sntB in 195 WT, ∆sntB, and Com-sntB strains was further detected by qRT-PCR and the result 196 showed that the expression of sntB was absent in the gene-deletion strains, and it fully 197 recovered in the Com-sntB (Figure S1), which reflected that the sntB and Com-sntB 198 had been constructed, and could be used in the subsequent experiments of this study. 199 The phenotype analysis of this study revealed that the deletion of sntB gene 200 significantly inhibited the growth of mycelium, hyphae morphology, the length of 201 fungal cell (between two adjacent septa), the number of conidiation, sclerotium 202
formation, and aflatoxin biosynthesis, while the above phenotypes of both 203 development and mycotoxin bio-synthesis were fully recovered in the Com-sntB 204 strain (Figure 1). To reveal the signaling pathways of sntB in conidiation, sclerotium 205 formation, and aflatoxin biosynthesis, qRT-PCR analysis was performed to assess the 206 expression levels of sporulation related transcriptional factor genes, steA, WetA, fluG, 207 and veA, sclerotia formation related transcriptional factor genes, nsdC, nsdD, and sclR 208 [46, 47] , and the AFs synthesis gene cluster structural genes aflC, aflR, and aflP, and the 209 main regulatory gene aflR and aflS. As shown in Figure S2, the relative expression 210 levels of these genes were significantly lower in the ΔsntB strain compared to that of 211 the WT strain, and recovered in the Com-sntB strain. These results indicated that SntB 212 regulates the conidiation, sclerotium formation, and aflatoxin biosynthesis by the 213 canonical signaling pathways mediated by these regulators. 214

226 SntB plays important role in virulence of A. flavus to both plant and animal hosts 227 In order to explore the effect of SntB on the fungal colonization ability, peanut and 228 maize kernels were infected with spore solution of each fungal strain. Compared with 229 WT, the conidiation yield of ΔsntB on the infected host was significantly reduced 230 (P<0.001) and no AFB1 could be detected on the hosts infected by ΔsntB, while in the 231 Com-sntB strain, the capacity to produce conidia and AFB1 on both crop kernels 232 recovered (Figure 2A-2C and Figure S3A). The role of sntB in fungal virulence to 233 animals was also investigated. As Figure 2D-2E shown, the survival rate of silkworms 234 injected by spores of ΔsntB strain was significantly higher than that from WT infected 235 larvae. There were less fungal mycelium, conidia, and AFB1 production on the dead 236 silkworms injected by ΔsntB compared to the silkworms from the WT injection 237 groups, but when the gene was reintroduced (i.e. the Com-sntB group), similar to 238 what found in the WT group, the survival rate of silkworms obviously dropped and 239 more fungal mycelium, conidia, and AFB1 produced on the dead silkworms (Figure 240
2F-2H). All the above results revealed that SntB plays an essential role in virulence of 241 A. flavus. 242 The capacity of fungal infection is closely related to secreted hydrolases, such as 243 amylase, lipase, protease, etc. In order to explore the effect of SntB on the activity of 244 hydrolases, the activities of amylase in the above each fungal strain were further 245 determined. The results showed that the colonies of ΔsntB produced almost no 246 degradation transparent circle after adding iodine solution compared with that of WT 247 and Com-sntB, which indicated that the activity of α-amylase in ΔsntB strain was 248 significantly reduced (P<0.001) (Figure S3B and S3C). This suggests that SntB plays 249 an important role in the fungal pathogenicity by changing the hydrolases activity of A. 250 flavus. 251

of sntB gene were analyzed by both ΔsntB and overexpression sntB genetic mutants [20] . 435 SntB deletion impaired several developmental processes, such as sclerotia formation 436 and heterokaryon compatibility, secondary metabolite synthesis, and ability to 437 colonize host seeds, which were consistent with our results (Figure 1 and 2). Unlike, a 438 complementation strain was constructed in this study which further clarified and 439 confirmed the function of sntB gene. In this study, the potential mechanism under 440 these effects were further analyzed by detection the related transcriptional factor 441 genes of sporulation (steA, WetA, fluG, and veA), sclerotia formation (nsdC, nsdD, and 442 sclR), and the AFs synthesis related genes aflC, aflD, aflO, aflP, and aflR (Figure S2). 443 In the RNA-seq data, we also found some DEGs related to AFs synthesis (aflB, aflE, 444 aflH, aflK, aflN, aflO, aflP, aflQ, aflR, aflS, aflV, and aflW) (Figure S6).
